text: Bartender: Yeah, they're sitting right over there.
Ferris: Oh, hi there!
Good to see you!
Ferris: Nice to see you too!
Ferris: Thanks for coming, I know you've been busy lately.
No problem!
Ferris: So, how is life treating you?
Actually, it's been rather tough...
Ferris: Hmm, I'm sorry to hear.
Ferris: Since we last spoke, you started doing game development, right?.
As a hobby, yeah.
Ferris: Natural development from your gaming and programming hobbies, I venture.
You know it!
I suppose so.
Don't forget my artsy side!
Ferris: Hehe, that's right!
Yep, full time even
Ferris: Oh yeah, I can see where your stress is coming from then.
Ferris: Your life must be pretty exciting now!
Exciting, but also scary!
Honestly, I'd prefer a little more security.
Ferris: I'm curious. What have you learned so far?
I've learned a lot about game design
Ferris: Well, that stands to reason. Did you watch these videos I get recommended all the time? How were they called?
Extra Credits?
Game Maker's Toolkit?
GDC talks?
Ferris: Yeah, those!
I've been watching quite a few of them, yeah!
Actually, I've mostly been reading articles and books.
Ferris: And, did any of these feature a certain suppremely handsome crab on the cover?
Hehe, I don't think you're featured on many Rust game dev books yet.
Ferris: Then better make some good games in Rust so people write books about it!
Ferris: What was the most interesting thing you learned?
Hmm, that's a tough one to come up with on the spot. Gimme a sec.
Ferris: Sure, take your time.
My crappy art has improved a lot
Ferris: Oh come on, your art was never "crappy"!
Ferris: How did you improve it though? Did you just draw a lot?
I've learned some new 3D graphics things I didn't know before.
Not just drawing, but yeah, lots of practice
Ferris: Do you mind elaborating? You know I mostly know about programming, so this is all quite new to me.
I've gotten into 3D modeling.
Ferris: That's cool! I bet it must feel nice actually *seeing* the things you make instead of just writing stuff.
It's a great feeling. Quite motivating, too!
Ferris: I bet!
Yes, but it's also a lot of work until things don't look weird or slightly off.
Ferris: I can imagine.
It's a bit demoralizing when you also see how *little* you got done after hours of work.

Ferris: I understand. Don't beat yourself up about it, every artist I've ever talked to has said something similar. It's just part of the process. Getting better takes time, but it's inevitable if you keep at it.
I've written a couple of cool shaders.
Ferris: Whenever I see shader code, it all looks like dark magic to me. Is it as different from regular programming as it looks?
You do have to think about things in a different way, yeah.
Ferris: I imagine. Maybe I should try it out sometime.
It's not that different, really.
Ferris: Huh, maybe I should give it a shot sometime then.
Ferris: Are there any other artsy things you can share? I enjoy hearing about things I don't know much yet about.
Hmm, lemme think.
Ferris: Sure, take your time.
Ferris: Wanna talk about what's troubling you?
I'd rather speak about something happier, actually
Ferris: Sure, I understand. Just know that I'm here if you ever want to talk about it.
Ferris: I bet you must have had some interesting new experiences, though.
I don't know if this is really what I want to do with my life
It started out great, but I'm not sure if I can keep it up
Ferris: What do you mean?
I thought developing games was about fun, but it's actually just draining me.
Ferris: I believe you. I've heard a lot about game developer burnout on Reddit.
Making games my job has sucked the fun out of them. I'm getting tired of them.
Ferris: I believe you. I think a lot of people who made their passion their job feel the same way.
Ferris: Are you working in a genre that you truly like?
Yes, and that's the problem
Ferris: So this genre that you used to love has now just become a chore, right?
Ferris: Maybe you could instead work in another genre and reserve your current one for off-work fun only.
Huh, that's actually an interesting idea.
I can't just throw away everything I built so far
Not really
Ferris: Maybe you feel like this because you're not really working on your passion, then.
Ferris: Maybe you could try switching genres and see where that leads you.
Huh, that's actually an interesting idea.
Ferris: I'm glad I could help!
I can't just throw away everything I built so far
Ferris: I'm pretty sure whatever you come up with with passion and love will be better than what you build with exhaustion.
Fair enough
Ferris: See! I'm always right!
Ferris: But seriously, I think you should give it a shot.
I'll think about it. Thanks, Ferris!
Ferris: You're welcome!
It's fun, but it's an incredible taxing and thankless job.
Ferris: I believe you. I've heard a lot about game developer burnout on Reddit.
It doesn't feel like a real "grown up" job.
Ferris: I'm sorry to hear that. Other than the opinions of others, do you feel fulfilled when you are working on a game?
When I'm in the middle of it? Yeah, I definitely feel a sense of flow.
Ferris: That's good to hear. If you enjoy the work itself, you're doing better than most people.
Ferris: You and me both see video games as an art form, right? That makes you an artist.
Ferris: And artists have always been belittled by others working in fields with more manual labor or obvious results.
Ferris: But the truth is that people like you shape our culture and society. You're doing important work.
Ferris: I'm proud of you for that, and I hope that you can be proud of yourself too.
Ferris: If anyone says otherwise, I advise you to either show them some cool art or stop talking to them.
Ferris: You deserve to be surrounded by people who believe in you.
I... wow.
Thanks, Ferris. I really needed to hear that.
Fair enough, but I can hardly stop talking to my family
Ferris: Tell them how important this is to you. If they don't understand, tell them to at least try and respect your choices.
Ferris: Your family loves you and would not want to lose you over something like this.
Ferris: I'm sure they'll come around, even if it doesn't seem like it right now.
I'll try. Thanks, Ferris.
Ferris: You're welcome. I'm always here for you.
Not really. It feels like all my friends are moving forward with their lives and I'm just... not.
Ferris: So you feel like you're missing out on something?
Yeah, that's it.
Not quite. It's more that I don't feel mature compared to others.
Ferris: Alright, I see. You know, it's okay to not quite know where you want to go in life.
Ferris: Others might seem like they've got everything figured out, but I guarantee you one thing.
Ferris: Everyone, and I tell you, *everyone* is just winging it.
Ferris: Me, your friends, your parents, your teachers, your boss, everyone.
Ferris: And that's okay. It's alright to stumble. So game development isn't quite your calling, that's fine.
Ferris: You're doing the best you can, and no one can ask more of you than that.
Ferris: I'm proud of what you achieved so far and I know you *will* find something that makes you as happy.
I... wow.
Thanks, Ferris. I really needed to hear that.
I'm not sure if I believe you, but thanks for trying.
Ferris: You're welcome. Remember that all of your friends are here for you if you need us.
Ferris: I'm sure you've heard the whole shebang about work-life balance a thousand times, but please remember to take care of yourself.
Ferris: You can't do your best work anyway if you're not feeling well.
I know, I know. But it's harder than it sounds.
Thing is, there is so much to do that I can't get anything done otherwise.
Ferris: Slow down there, Atlas. You can't carry the whole world on your shoulders.
Ferris: Have you tried reducing your scope? Maybe you could keep track of what takes the most time and find a way to cut it down.
Ferris: I'll give you an example: the guy behind the game "A Short Hike" knew that he didn't have enough time to make high-quality 3D models for the character.
Ferris: So, he instead added an aggressive pixelation filter on top of the whole thing. Now, the pixels are so big that any detail would be lost anyway.
Ferris: Which means that the details are all created in the best renderer of all: your imagination.
Ferris: And that is precisely one of the reasons why the game is so charming. It looks and feels gorgeous, despite very little time spent on the actual models.
Fair enough, that is worth considering.
Ferris: I'm glad I could help!
???: Oh hi there! You peeps are also here?
Ferris: Oh hi Clippy!
Clippy: WhazZzZuUUuup!
Ferris: WhAzzZzuuuUUP!
WHazzZZUUuuUp!
Everyone: WHAZZZZZUUUUUUUUUUPPPP!
You two are still doing that?
Ferris & Clippy: WHAAZZZZZZUUUUUUUUUUPPPP!
